abstract: Farhad Manjoo picks four products from 2014 that are bringing the future closer.
snippet: Farhad Manjoo picks four products from 2014 that are bringing the future closer.
lead_paragraph: LOTS of cool new technology products come out every year, but usually only a few stand out. These few, though, are often mind-bending — they alter your perspective of what’s possible in the future. There were four such technologies for me in 2014:

headline.main: Standouts in Tech: Drones, Virtual Reality, Instant Translation and A.I.
headline.print_headline: Innovation in 2014: 4 Standouts in Tech

abstract: By Jan. 1, 29 states and the District of Columbia will have minimum wages above the federal minimum wage of $7.25.

abstract: Minimum wage increases go into effect in 20 states and the District of Columbia by Jan. 1, and, all told, 29 states will exceed the federal minimum of $7.25 an hour at the beginning of January.
snippet: Minimum wage increases go into effect in 20 states and the District of Columbia by Jan. 1, and, all told, 29 states will exceed the federal minimum of $7.25 an hour at the beginning of January.

headline.print_headline: Hourly Wage Is Going Up for Millions

abstract: Jill Denny and Jeff Chen are anything but average.
snippet: Jill Denny and Jeff Chen are anything but average.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Happy New Year! I hope everyone is enjoying welcoming in Baby New Year in the most pleasant way possible. Mine is relatively quiet: It will involve lots of food and binge-watching the BBC America “Doctor Who” marathon with my nearest and dearest, which is just right after all the noise of 2014. Many thanks to the unbelievably dapper Tom Gaffney for holding the fort while I was away.

headline.main: Average

abstract: One of the foremost challenges is finding a way to get the world’s major economies humming enough that deflation is no longer a worry.
snippet: One of the foremost challenges is finding a way to get the world’s major economies humming enough that deflation is no longer a worry.
lead_paragraph: It was a confounding year in global financial markets. Not because it was a disaster for most investors; American stocks and bonds both rose in value. It was confounding because of some major moves that defied expert consensus this time a year ago — not only what was predicted, but what was even thought plausible.

headline.main: Five Surprising Economic Trends in 2014, and What They Mean for 2015
headline.print_headline: Market Trends of 2014: What They Mean for 2015

snippet: By adopting tabletlike, touch-screen systems, automakers are integrating smartphones and online services with fewer complicated controls that frustrate and distract drivers.

abstract: Celebrate some of our national holidays this month.

The holidays are over and the decorations have hopefully been put away. Or if they haven’t, no worries; we don’t judge. But we need something to keep us occupied until the spring thaw.

snippet: State and local governments are spending on projects that were stalled — like an effort in Naples, Fla., to prevent pelicans from entangling fishing lines — and even some federal spending is rising.

headline.main: To Rescue Economy, Japan Turns to Supermom
headline.print_headline: To Rescue Economy, Japan Turns to Supermom

headline.main: A Year of Columns, a Memorable Trove of Characters
headline.print_headline: A Year of Columns, a Memorable Trove of Characters

If you were hoping to start out the New Year with a nice, easy Monday, you’re out of luck.

abstract: In the short term, the drop in the oil prices will make it harder to get deals done. But if low prices persist, financial stress may make small players vulnerable, Fiona Maharg-Bravo of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
snippet: In the short term, the drop in the oil prices will make it harder to get deals done. But if low prices persist, financial stress may make small players vulnerable, Fiona Maharg-Bravo of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: There was $383 billion in mergers and acquisitions in the oil and gas sector last year, as of Dec. 11. Yet Europe has largely missed out: About three-quarters of the targets have been in North America, according to Thomson Reuters data. Shale has played a big role. In 2015, oil and gas bankers in Europe will get a bigger slice of the action.

headline.main: Oil Price Slump May Spur European Oil and Gas Deal-Making

abstract: But will the trend continue in 2015? Strategists offer their predictions.
snippet: But will the trend continue in 2015? Strategists offer their predictions.
lead_paragraph: OVER the last three or four Januarys, the advice for investing in bonds has been remarkably consistent. It’s gone something like this: Beware of them, because inflation is going to rise, interest rates are going to spike and bond holders are going to lose enormous amounts of money. When it came to losses, comparisons were made to what happened to equities in 2008.

headline.main: For Bond Investors, Ignoring Expert Advice Has Been Profitable
headline.print_headline: For Bond Investors, Ignoring Expert Advice Has Been Profitable

abstract: Ferran Adrià, a groundbreaking Spanish chef whose El Bulli was one of the world’s top restaurants before he closed it, is now on an idiosyncratic quest for knowledge and creativity.
snippet: Ferran Adrià, a groundbreaking Spanish chef whose El Bulli was one of the world’s top restaurants before he closed it, is now on an idiosyncratic quest for knowledge and creativity.
lead_paragraph: One day in November, Ferran Adrià, the Spanish chef who turned foods into foams and pioneered a new era in gastronomic innovation while running one of the world’s most popular restaurants, bounced through a loft space in Barcelona. He peered at pencil-sketched mind maps tacked to plastic foam bulletin boards and examined books jammed on narrow shelves — until he reached the end of a display table featuring a variety of Asian soup spoons. Then he stopped.

headline.main: Ferran Adrià Feeds the Hungry Mind
headline.print_headline: Feeding the Hungry Mind

abstract: Take a walk with me through Sam Ezersky’s wonderful Saturday puzzle.
snippet: Take a walk with me through Sam Ezersky’s wonderful Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Have you ever traveled to a new town with no real plan for exploring and just meandered along the streets, taking in the sights as you go? I love doing that, because it’s the best way to stumble upon the hidden jewels that a town has to offer. That’s precisely how solving Sam Ezersky’s fine puzzle felt to me. I wandered around his grid, laughing and learning as I went, and that is the best possible outcome one can hope for on a Saturday.

abstract: Amazon’s “all you can eat” reading service, Kindle Unlimited, is driving down prices even as it boosts sales. For self-published authors, that’s a cause for concern.
snippet: Amazon’s “all you can eat” reading service, Kindle Unlimited, is driving down prices even as it boosts sales. For self-published authors, that’s a cause for concern.
lead_paragraph: One big argument for “all you can eat” music, video and book services is that they encourage people to sample new artists and ultimately develop a deeper relationship with a few of them. You listen to songs you have never heard before because there is no additional cost, and then maybe you go to the concert and, perhaps, buy a T-shirt. Artists are rewarded at the end of the process, not in the beginning the way they used to be.

headline.main: For the Indie Writers of Amazon, It’s Publish or Perish
headline.print_headline: For the Indie Writers of Amazon, Itu2019s Publish or Perish

abstract: The president of Hope Family Wines enjoys working the vineyards, but when work called for formal attire, a luggage problem called for quick thinking.
snippet: The president of Hope Family Wines enjoys working the vineyards, but when work called for formal attire, a luggage problem called for quick thinking.
lead_paragraph: IT seems that I’ve been in an airplane most of my life. When I was younger I raced professionally in motocross. I did the national circuit and we traveled all over the country. My family started planting grapes in 1978. I remember getting into a little trouble at school once and my dad said if I didn’t shape up he was going to make me work the vineyards. I thought working on the land was the coolest thing ever, which probably wasn’t the reaction he wanted. But there is a great joy to be found when you’re working a vineyard and seeing grapes develop and grow. I don’t know how I did it, but somehow I managed to get my college degree in fruit science from California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo. Now I’m president and winemaker for our business, Hope Family Wines, including Treana, and I’m still traveling all the time.

headline.main: Fit for the Job, Even in an Ill-Fitting Suit
headline.print_headline: Fit for the Job, Even in an Ill-Fitting Suit

lead_paragraph: The Irish drug maker Shire has agreed to acquire NPS Pharmaceuticals for $5.2 billion, the first big corporate acquisition of the year, DealBook’s David Gelles reports. Shire, based in Dublin, said on Sunday that it would pay $46 a share for NPS, which is based in New Jersey and specializes in drugs for gastrointestinal disorders. That represents a 51 percent increase over NPS’s share price on Dec. 16, before rumors of the deal first surfaced. Shire will pay for NPS using all cash.

lead_paragraph: Viacom, the media group that includes MTV, Comedy Central and Nickelodeon as well as the Paramount film studio, has extended the contract of its chief executive and president, Philippe Dauman, until 2018, the company said Thursday. His contract was set to expire in 2016. Mr. Dauman, 60, a lawyer and deal maker, became chief in 2006, beating out rivals from the creative side of the company to install himself as the leading candidate to succeed the executive chairman and founder, Sumner M. Redstone, 91. Mr. Redstone said Mr. Dauman had “been an extraordinary C.E.O.” and “his strategic vision and creative leadership have delivered consistently outstanding operational and financial results.” Mr. Dauman received $37.2 million in 2013 in salary, stock and options. In the quarter that ended last September, ratings for Viacom’s networks dropped 15 percent, though Mr. Dauman pointed out that ratings failed to take account of other platforms.

abstract: Consumers replaced worn-out models and analysts said they expected a modest upward trend again this year.
snippet: Consumers replaced worn-out models and analysts said they expected a modest upward trend again this year.
lead_paragraph: The European auto market grew last year for the first time since before the global financial crisis began, industry data showed on Friday, as consumers replaced worn-out models and analysts said they expected a modest upward trend again this year. New passenger car registrations, a proxy for sales, rose 5.7 percent in the European Union last year, reaching about 12.6 million vehicles, the European Automobile Manufacturer’s Association reported from Brussels. It was the first annual expansion since 2007, when the market peaked at nearly 16 million new passenger cars. Spain led the major national markets in 2014, with government trade-in incentives helping to lift sales by more than 18 percent. Germany, Europe’s largest auto market, grew 2.9 percent. Still, the industry is not out of danger. The stagnant economy in most of Europe, as well as crushing unemployment in countries like Greece and Spain, will continue to weigh on the market. LMC Automotive, a market research firm, estimates that European sales will gain just 1.1 percent in 2015. Carlos Da Silva, who follows Europe’s car market at IHS Automotive, said in a research note that the 2014 recovery was welcome news, but that Europe was not yet “a fully cured patient.”

headline.main: Car Market Shows Signs of Revival for Europe
headline.print_headline: Car Market Shows Signs of Revival for Europe

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — On a tour of central Henan Province in May of last year, China’s president, Xi Jinping, first raised the notion of the economy adjusting to a “new normal.” Eight months later, with the economy growing at its slowest pace in more than two decades, it is increasingly clear what this adjustment will mean for China.

lead_paragraph: At the end of his book “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” Thomas Piketty proposes a global wealth tax to help address the problem of runaway income inequality. In contrast with the careful research that went into the book, the suggestion of a global wealth tax struck many tax policy veterans as naïve and unhelpful.

headline.main: Echoes of Piketty in Obama Proposal to Address Income Inequality

abstract: By understanding and evaluating our exposure, we can gain valuable control over our lives when the world is seemingly out of control.
snippet: By understanding and evaluating our exposure, we can gain valuable control over our lives when the world is seemingly out of control.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a conversation with a friend reminded me how easily we can confuse actual risk with our own exposure to that risk. My friend travels a lot for work, and I asked him where he planned to go this year. His answer surprised me. “I don’t know,” he replied. “With everything going on in the world, I’m not sure I want to travel as much.”

headline.main: Exposure Offers Clarity in the Risky World of Investing

lead_paragraph: Marissa Mayer, the chief executive of Yahoo, said on Tuesday that the Internet company would spin off its 15.4 percent stake in Alibaba, China’s leading e-commerce company, into a separate company, Vindu Goel and Michael J. de la Merced report in The New York Times. Shareholders will directly reap all the remaining profit from Yahoo’s investment, which cost almost nothing a decade ago but is now worth about $39.5 billion. The Alibaba stake alone now makes up nearly 85 percent of Yahoo’s market value. Shares of Yahoo rose about 7 percent in after-hours trading after disclosure of the plan.

abstract: David Steinberg cracks me up.

lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — At the end of this post, I’m going to direct you to a very touching tribute to our own Bernice Gordon, who died on Thursday at the age of 101. It was written by today’s constructor, David Steinberg, who collaborated with Ms. Gordon on these two puzzles. Besides being delightful to solve, theirs was a collaboration that covered multiple generations and was the basis of an incredible friendship. I highly encourage you to give it a read.
